Award.AwardTitle: Smoky Mountains / Great Plains Geometry Conference 2016
Award.AbstractNarration:
This award provides partial participant support for the Smoky Great Plains Geometry Conference, held August 18-12, 2016, in Townsend, Tennessee. The conference centers on modern developments in geometric analysis and metric geometry. These two closely related fields have played a large role in recent years in advancing several areas of mathematics. Those contributions include the solutions of a number of very famous unsolved problems in mathematics, not only in geometry but also in number theory, topology, and other areas. For example, recent solution of the 100-year-old Poincar√© Conjecture relied heavily on methods from geometric analysis and metric geometry. This area of mathematics also has applications to physics, chemistry, engineering, and big data analysis. The conference encourages and supports participation by members of groups underrepresented in mathematics.

The technical areas represented in the conference are global and comparison Riemannian geometry, special Riemannian metrics (Einstein, Ricci solitons, and generalizations), isometric group actions, positive curvature, metric geometry, and Alexandrov geometry. The conference features eight plenary speakers and approximately ten shorter talks by early-career mathematicians. The conference activities will bring together leading experts and young researchers and students, facilitating the dissemination of recent research progress and discussion of future directions and open problems. These interactions are expected to lead to cross-fertilization between the more specialized topics presented at the conference and to future progress in both geometric analysis and metric geometry. The conference webpage is available at http://sgpc.math.utk.edu/.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The award supported the mathematics conference “Reflections on Global Riemannian Geometry”, which was the third annual conference in the series “Smoky Great Plains Geometry Conference”. The conference alternates between Wichita State University and the University of Tennessee-Knoxville. The conference was held in Townsend, Tennessee, near Knoxville. The international conference involved 54 participants from around the United States and five foreign countries. The conference began on Thursday, Aug. 18, 2016 and ended on Sunday, Aug. 21, 2016.  There were nine plenary talks and around ten shorter talks by early career mathematicians. Between talks there was ample time for mathematical discussions and exchange of ideas.

 

The conference met its goal of having at least half of the speakers be female (10/19), which is a departure from many mathematics conferences in which women are underrepresented among speakers. The award provided support to participants, including lodging and full or partial travel support. No honoraria or other compensation was paid from the award. 62% of the travel and lodging support was awarded to early career researchers consisting of graduate students and postdoctoral researchers.

 

The subject of the conference was Riemannian Geometry, which is a branch of differential geometry. This area of mathematics involves the study of shapes in many (sometimes infinite) dimensions. It is important in its own right and has connections and applications to many other areas of mathematics, including topology, partial differential equations and algebra (for example Lie Groups) as well as applications to physics, image processing, data science, robotics, chemistry and biological sciences.

 

The website for the conference is http://sgpc.math.utk.edu/ and videos of the talks are available online. The conference also received support for refreshments and other expenses from the Department of Mathematics, the University of Tennessee, and Wichita State University.

 

Intellectual Merit: Riemannian geometry is a central sub-field of mathematics that is highly active and has applications to many fields. Conference participants represented major universities across the United States and from several foreign countries. The conference featured nineteen speakers in diverse branches of differential geometry, and participants had ample time for additional discussions.

 

Broader Impacts: Diversity was an important factor to the organizers of the conference. More than half of the speakers were women, a group underrepresented in mathematics and (even more severely) speakers at major mathematics conferences. The conference also provided most of the financial support to early career researchers, who traditionally have fewer resources for travel than established mathematicians.
